sp.p: I find by Victoria's expoſing me to Captain Heart • , her conſenting to have Bisket, is all Hypocriſy, I'm reſolv'd to watch her well, and no Meſſenger from Major Buck ſhall enter here without my Examination; what a miſerable Paſſion Love is, like Poverty, it forces us to many mean Actions we are aſnamed on; I have ſome Remorſe on Victoria's Account—and think it ſhocking that ſhe muſt be forc'd to marry the Man ſhe hates, but what would I not do to gain my Major Buck.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: (Aſide.) This muſt be the Lady, by the Deſcription my Maſter has given me—Madam, if your Name's Victoria, I was ordered to deliver this Letter into your own Hands.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Ha! 'tis Major Buck—his Footman —opening a Letter directed to Victoria is Barbarous —but the little God of Love muſt Anſwer for every Action that Paſſion hurries us to—

body.p:
CAPTAIN Hearty has given me ſome Hopes of your not liking the Coxcomb your Parents have provided as a Husband for you; I beg you would give me leave to put
it out of the Power of their making you Miſerable; Hearty has informed me they have agreed you ſhall Marry in the Dark, and if you give me the leaſt Hopes—I'll perſonate the Santiſta, and your Father ſhall give you to me; and as it will be his own Act and Deed, I doubt not of his being ſoon reconcil'd to us, for all my Eſtate ſtall be ſettled as he thinks fit; If you agree not to this, I am the miſerableſt Wretch now living.

closer.signed: I am, Your Admirer, MAJOR BUCK.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Heark'e, Friend—tell the Major I like his Plot exceedingly well, and will punctually obſerve his Letter—there's ſomething for your Pains— (gives him Money.)

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: (Aſide) —By this Light a Moeda.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: If you meet any of the Family, deny your Buſineſs here and to whom you belong.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: I was ordered by my Maſter, Madam, to Foreſwear every Thing—Lying handſomely was the firſt Qualification he took a liking to me for.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Admirable cunning Witch, I'll ſpoil their Dark Intrigue, and fit 'em with Hypocriſy; and ſince he will Perſonate this Bisket, I'll be his Victoria, and make him mine in ſpite of all his cunning Plots.

div.stage: Enter Brigadier General Conqueſt, Mackentoſh, and Cadwallader.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: I knew it muſt be a Feint of the Enemy; they had only a mind to change the Situation of their Camp, for the better conveniency of Forage.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Af the Portugueſe General were of my Mind, and the Spaniards wonnot Attack us, bred we would Attack them.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: Cot knows, if I was within Arms length of a Tozen of my Enemies, here I wot haſ them, and there I wot haſ them, till they lookt like a Plew Apron.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: Your Bravery, Gentlemen, wants ſome Conduct to govern it, the Conſequence of a Battle, were we beaten, might be the ruin of Portugal, for the Enemy wou'd March immediately to Lisbon.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: B • t an we lay'd about us with a gued Will, we wanno leave Lags enow for them to March thither with, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: And py my good will many of them ſhou't go thither without their Heads.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: If the whole Army had your Gallantry and Reſolution, much might be done, but in a Number of Men there are always ſome Baſhful on • .

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Gued Faith, I'll anſwer for our own Regiment, not a Man of us will duck his Head at a Cannon Ball.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p:
Splutter her Nails I have a Company of pol •
Prittains ſhall make Toaſted Cheeſe of 'em, and devour 'em when they have ton.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: I hope before the Campaign is over, we ſhall have occaſion to Try their Courage—have you many Criminals for the Court-Martial.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Only a Fellow that committed a Rape, with Thieves and a Deſerter.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: Indeed we want Men, ſo that it 'tis for the goot of the Service to Hang no Poty.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: They are Summon'd to appear at my Quarters, and you are Preſident.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Yes, gend Sir, and 'tis now about the Time of meeting, and they can pack out Officers that are well enough to make a Bord.

div.stage: Enter Major Buck, Wildiſh, Hearty, O'Rourk, Luconnel, and Footman.

sp.speaker: Major Buck.
sp.p: (to his Fostmon,) thou haſt perform'd wonders, and ſhe was very much pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Prodigiouſly overjoy'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: (E ••• ing of them.) So, Gentlemen, you may Sleep in whole Skins, for this Night.

sp.speaker: Major Buck
sp.p: (Aſide) I am very glad on't, for methinks I'd willingly be married before I'm knock'd on the Head.

sp.speaker: Maj. O'Rourk
sp.p: By my Shoule, I did lay a Vager with my nownſelf, dat dere vid be no Battle, and fait now I have won.

sp.speaker: Col. Mac.
sp.p: Wall, Sir,— (to ORourk.) than you will be ſtall at your • riciſm, waunds, Sir, I naver mat a Man of Sance that came out of your country, but Major Buck, there.

sp.speaker: Capt. Luc.
sp.p: He is de very pritty Gentilman, he love de Ingenneer very well.

sp.speaker: Maj. O'Rourk.
sp.p: Arrah, by my Shoul now I have catch'd you, dear joy, for he was born at Mac Farty, in the County of Tipperary, as well as my ſelf, he did Suck of the ſame Nurſe, he did Eat his Potatoes out of the ſame Backſide, and his Bonny Clabber came from my Moder's Bull: Den how de Devil ſhou'd he have more Sence den I, by St. Patrick, he only ſpeaks his vords one way, and I do ſpeak them an oder vay, but we do mean de ſame Ting.

sp.speaker: Maj. Buck.
sp.p: Exactly, my dear Country man.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: You are merry Gentlemen truly.

sp.speaker: Capt. Luc.
sp.p: Jerny Divil if de Enemy no make a de Attack, vat vil de Battery ſigniſie.

sp.speaker: Col. Mac.
sp.p: Jaſt as much, Sir, as if they had made an Attack, it would have been of no uſe.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: Cot knows, then it wout have pin like him ſelf.

sp.speaker: Capt. Luc.
sp.p: You are de Gentilmens Soultiers, dat know hou to mount de Brech, beat a de Parley, Exchange a de Hoſtage, make a de Article, and take a de Town, but you know noting of de Fortifications, I am de Gentilman, dat can make a de Hornwork, and de Crownwork before de curtain, de ſingle Tenaille, de double Tenaille, de Fort, de Citadell, de Mine, and de Draw-Brige, begar, clap a de Ravelin upon de Ravelin, and keep a de Town from a Surrenter, ten Undred Thouſand Year.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: If I hat a Prittain in my Company, ſhout tell me ſuch a ſtory, I know what I wot tell him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I have ſeen him throw a Bomb into a Snuff-Box.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: Will you juſtify this to any Shentleman's face, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt. Luc.
sp.p: Tis very true begar.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p:
Ay and ſeen him ſhoot a Cannon Ball point
blank between a Spaniſh Horſe's Legs, and take away nothing but his Tale.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: Are you a Man of Honour, Sir, and tell ſuch a parcel of what ſhall I call 'em.

sp.speaker: Capt Luc.
sp.p: I remember de Ting ver well, it was upon de Wager.

sp.speaker: Maj. Buck.
sp.p: But I ſhall never forget his Blowing up the Citadel without ſpringing a Mine, or having any Gun-Powder to do it with.

sp.speaker: Capt. Luc.
sp.p: Oh I had ſerved twenty Citadels ſo before dat.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: Plow up the Citadel without Gun Powder, dere is my Glove—any Shentleman that will pretent to inſiſt upon the truth of this Tings, by St. Tavit, I will have his Plout.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: What do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Cadw.
sp.p: I toe mean, Sir, that every Soultier ought to pe a Man of Honour, that will ſtant to every Ting he ſays, or peg Parten for telling of Lyes; who takes up my Glove?

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: Prithee Cadwallader, take up the Glove your ſelf, or I ſhall confine you, don't you perceive theſe Gentlemen are merry.

sp.speaker: Col. Mac.
sp.p: Can you not find out, Man, that they talk theſe ſtorys to laugh at tha French man, and not affront you, Sir, but you would be a better Man than you are, if you could govern your Paſſions better.

sp.speaker: Cadw.
sp.p: Why if the General to think me in the wrong, Cot knows, I will eat my Glove my ſelf, and kiſs you all rount, put the Frenchman here.

sp.speaker: Capt. Luc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, for all dat, I cannot help tinking my ſelf de greateſt Ingeneer in de hole Vorld, notwithſtanding your Vauborn, Cohorn, and dem Gentlemen

sp.speaker: Col. Mac.
sp.p: Wounds, Sir, an I cannot help thinking another Thing.

sp.speaker: Capt. Luc.
sp.p: Vat is that, my good Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col. Mac.
sp.p: That you are the conceitedeſt ſally Fellow, that your Country ever bred, Sir, and ge • d faith, they have b • ed abundance.

sp.speaker: Maj. O'Rourk
sp.p:
By my Shoul, and ſo they have, Sir, arrah, I know ſeveral of his Countrymen, dat have
been Born and Bred in Ireland, and dey have been very ſilly Fellows, but very great Matematicians, by my Shoul.

sp.speaker: Maj. Buck.
sp.p: Well ſaid, my dear Countryman.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: Will theſe Animoſities and Country Reflections never ceaſe, for ſhame Gentlemen, be more united amongſt yourſelves, if you're ſo mutinous when Sober, ſhure you're very quarrelſome in your Drink.

sp.speaker: Col. Mac.
sp.p: Geud faith, Sir, Sober or Drunk I'le always ſpeak Truth, an I would have Flatter'd, Sir, I woul't have a Regiment afore now.

sp.speaker: Cadw.
sp.p: An I whot have pin as unjuſt as other People, I wot have pin very Rich.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: Are all theſe Gentlemen upon the Court-Martial.

sp.speaker: Col. Mac.
sp.p: Ary Soul on 'm, Sir.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: The more haſte you make to diſpatch it in, the more time we ſhall have for Mirth; generous Wine is the great preſervative of our Healths, in theſe ſickly Times, and I'll give you a Bottle of the beſt in Portugal,—come, Gentlemen, let us March, — (he goes out, the reſt of the Company following him.)

sp.speaker: Maj. O'Rourk.
sp.p: (To Major Buck.) by my Shoul, my dear Major, I was very glad to ſee you, before I did hear you was come from England

sp.speaker: Maj. Buck.
sp.p: (Mimtcking of him,) Arrah, my dear Countryman, I will be after kiſſing of you for your Friendſhips.

sp.speaker: Maj. O'Rourk.
sp.p: If I was to live a Hundred Years, by my Shoul I would tay to Morrow, that I might ſerve you.

div.stage: Enter Serjeant File-off, Charlotte, Clara, Willmot, and other Soldiers.

sp.speaker: File off.
sp.p: So, Sir, March 'em this way—take long ſtrides, turn out your Toes—keep the diſtance of your Pike from 'em, and once in four Steps look back with a ſcornful Countenance,—very well, now halt, face about upon one Heel, ſtick your Pike in the Ground, ſhake your Head,—and with a terrible Voice, cry Silence.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Silence.

sp.speaker: File-off.
sp.p: Now pull out your Snuff-Box, walk pragmatically two or three Times along the Front, give your half Pike to your Foot-Boy—and Erect your Cane with a ſort of a Flouriſh—now you may if you pleaſe Swear a Hundred Oaths at each Soldier— tho' of late that part of the Diſcipline is left off, for the more Subſtantial one of Caning,—ſee that every Soldier ſtands Erect, turns out his Toes and lets his Firelock hang eaſy on his Shoulder—now, Sir, give your ſelf a few Military Airs.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (Strikes one of the Fellows.) Is that a Poſture for a Gentleman Soldier, Sirrah, (to another.) who cockt your Cap for you. Dog, ha!—(to another) I'll teach you to roll your Neckcloth better Villain, (to another) how dare you appear without powder'd Hair, and a clean Shirt, do you think you five Pence a Day is allow'd you only to Eat and Drink with, Raſcal— to Willmot—what the Devil for a Fellow have we got here, clap your Piece thus, Sirrah, your Hand here, and hold up your Head, or I'll knock it off your Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: This is a worſe Plague than any I have yet met with.

sp.speaker: File off.
sp.p: Upon my Honour, Sir, you take Notice of every Thing as exactly, as if you had been a Major this thirty Years.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: What's the meaning of your Lock being ſo ruſty, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.p: Why I ſtood Centry in the Rain, I'm put upon double Duty, and had not Time to clean it.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (Beats him.) do you mutter, Sirrah, how dare you pretend to give a Reaſon for any Thing I have a mind to find Fault with.

sp.speaker: File-off.
sp.p: No General Officer could have ſaid a more Soldier like Thing, than that.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I find my Miſtreſs is reſolved to be Revenged upon the whole Sex—

sp.speaker: File-off.
sp.p: Now, Sir, pray try if you can Remember the Exerciſe.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Silence — Clap your Right Hand to your Firelocks.

sp.speaker: File-off.
sp.p: (To the Soldiers) altogether there.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Porſe your Firelocks—to Wilmot— Villain, I'll ſtick you if thou do'ſt not mind the Words of Command.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: I wiſh he would, that I might be eas'd of his Damn'd Impertinence.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Reſt your Fire locks, Fools, Blockheads, Dogs, do it all together.

sp.speaker: File off.
sp.p: That Paſſion of Yours is very graceful, and is one of the politeſt Parts of the Art Military.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (beats Wilmot.) Villain, I'll have thee tied Neck and Heels immediately, thou awkward Dog.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: My Soul's above taking a Blow from ſuch a Raſcal as thou art (preſenting his Piece.) therefore at they Heart.

div.stage: The Serjeant knocks the Piece out of his Hand, and they ſeize him.

sp.speaker: File-off.
sp.p: What is the Fellow mad, mutinying againſt your Officer, and Conſpiring his Death, thou wilt be Shot, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh! Heavens what an Eſcape was here.

sp.speaker: File-off.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, Sir, we'll carry him to the Prova's, the Court Martial ſits immediately, he may be Condemn'd to Day and Shot to morrow.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: The ſooner the better, I'm weary of my Life, and wiſh to loſe it.

sp.speaker: 1. Sold.
sp.p: Nay I can come in as a witneſs to prove he is a bloody minded Dog.

sp.speaker: 2d Sold.
sp.p: And I heard him ſay when Roger and I were talking politickly of our coming from England to ſupport the Portugueſe againſt Arbitrary Power and Popery, and to maintain them in Liberty and Property and ſo forth, he made Anſwer they might go and he Damn'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Sold.
sp.p: No, he did not ſay ſo bad as that, neither, he only wiſh'd 'em all at the Devil.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Drag him along murdering Raſcal, I'll ſee the End of him.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: As I would of thee if was I at Liberty.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Pray hold him faſt.

sp.speaker: File-off.
sp.p: Here—you two March before him, —and you two follow him if he offers to make his Eſcape, ſhoot him Dead on the Spot.

sp.speaker: 1. Sold.
sp.p: As a Herring Serjeant, I warrant you— I have an old Ninimoſity againſt him, and therefore will be ſure to lodge my Bullets as near his Heart as I can.

sp.speaker: File-off.
sp.p: (At the Head of 'em) march.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Charlotte and Clara.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: 'Tis well he is ſecur'd, I tremble every Joint of me; what, dear Madam, could provoke you to run this Hazard.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Revenge, Revenge, my dear Clara, I'm weary of my Life, and ſince I've loſt my Willmot, I'll conſpire the Death of all his Sex.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And ſo die in the Attempt; pray give o'er theſe bloody-minded Reſolutions, confeſs yourſelf a Woman, and let's take the firſt Opportunity of returning to England.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I'm reſolv'd to ſignalize myſelf before I leave the Army, and let the World ſee how much they are miſtaken in my Sex's Cowardice. Come along, Clara I'll gain a Regiment, and make thee a Captain.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, I vow I think your Courage inſpires me.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: 'Tis about the Time I promiſed my Captain to attend him at the General's, come along, my Girl.

div.l: How well, how great 'twill look in after Story,
When they ſhall read a Woman gain'd this Glory,
To fight, to vanquiſh, govern and command,
And like a Hero dy'd with Sword in Hand.

sp.speaker: 2. Enſi.
sp.p: Why, here now have I taken Money for Brandy, and gone and loſt it at the Pinch-Office; nay, Brandy won't ſetch it again: I muſt lug out my Livelyhood the Moment Brother Surly comes, that's certain —why the Devil ſhould I grudge fighting with him for thirty Shillings, when every Day I venture my Life for Two and Six pence.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Oh! your Servant, Sir; well, where's the Brandy.

sp.speaker: 2. Enſi.
sp.p:
Why, hav'ent—you—got it—I—
I—and you hant it; my Dog of a Servant; and ſo you have not got it.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Lookee, Sir, I'm well aſſur'd neither you nor I have it; you have loſt my Money at the Pinch-Office, brag'd of over-reaching me, and made me the laughing Stock of the Company; therefore draw.

sp.speaker: 2. Enſi.
sp.p: Draw—ay, with all my Heart; and you poſitively have not had the Brandy; why then, I'll make it my Bargain, if I kill you, it ſhall be in full of all Accounts: I'll give your Executors and Adminiſtrators no farther Satisfaction—then Witneſs my Hand, and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I'll give you a Receipt in full for your Jeſt immediately; come, Sir—as they are going to fight, enter firſt Enſign, his Hat full of Money, goes between 'em.

sp.speaker: 1. Enſi.
sp.p: What, becauſe the Enemy won't fight with us, we muſt quarrel amongſt ourſelves, muſt we? Put up your Swords, or I ſwear by the Pinch-Office I'll throw a Handful in your Faces, and demoliſh your Countenances, ſo that you ſhall loſe the Uſe of 'em.

sp.speaker: 2. Enſi.
sp.p: Ha! Gold (throwing away his Sword) Sir, I beg my Life with all my Heart, I'm ſorry I have offended you: my dear Comrade, I adore thee; put on my Hat, you'll catch cold.

sp.speaker: 1. Enſi.
sp.p: None of your coaxing—here, take a Pocket full, and pay your Debts.

sp.speaker: 2. Enſi.
sp.p: There, Sir, (to Surly.) there's your paultry Sum, I ſcorn to be in any Man's Debt, I love to pay every Body his own, and no Body can charge me with doing any Thing that's unlike a Man of Honour, and an Officer.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Why, Brother, your Friend and Servant, and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: 1. Enſi.
sp.p: Do you know of any Body that has a mind to part with a Regiment; I'll either buy a Regiment, or go and keep a Bank.

sp.speaker: 2. Enſi.
sp.p: By all means keep a Bank: If we thrive, there will be Money enough to buy two Regiments.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: And if you don't.

sp.speaker: 2. Enſi.
sp.p: Why we ſhall be juſt in the ſame Condition we were in an Hour ago.

sp.speaker: 1. Enſi.
sp.p: Oh! Serjeant, did you go to my Man.

sp.speaker: File-off.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, and he told me you had bamboard me, and he was ſure, I was bit: For there had not been a Moeda in your green Purſe ſince the laſt Pay-Day.

sp.speaker: 1. Enſi.
sp.p: An impudent Dog, to diſgrace his Maſter ſo; I'll pay him his Wages, and force him to carry Arms. —Here, Serjeant, I never let a Man come twice after me for Money.

sp.speaker: File-off.
sp.p: I always ſaid you were an honourable Gentleman—there is a Court-Martial at the General's Quarters. I was order'd by the Preſident to deſire you would all attend there immediately: I ſuppoſe you have been ſummon'd already.

sp.speaker: 1. Enſi.
sp.p: Adſo, muſt I ſpend none of my Money till the Court-Martial is over; that will be a deviliſh Self-denial; but come along.

sp.speaker: 2. Enſi.
sp.p: Let's be ſerious, we are to be Judges of Life and Death.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: And to hang, draw and quarter with ourſelves.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Con.
sp.p: I Have told the General my Reſolution, and he's well pleas'd they ſhould be marry'd this Night; he thinks it a very ſilly Whim of the Girl to have the Ceremony perform'd in the Dark; but however I have perſuaded him to conſent to it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Since 'tis her Fancy, I would by no means have you againſt it, (aſide.) 'tis the only Stratagem I have, or can propoſe, to make Major Buck mine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Con.
sp.p: After the Court-martial, my Huſband has invited all the Officers to ſup with him; he'll ſteal out and have the Ceremony perform'd, and then ſurprize them with the Wedding.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then I hope Mirth will crown the Evening, (Aſide.) and much Company will favour my Deſign.

div.stage: Enter Biſket dreſt like a Fop.

sp.speaker: Biſk.
sp.p:
How do you like me now, my dear Mother inLaw—won't
this Sight win her Heart, Belinda▪

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your Dreſs is very elegant.

sp.speaker: Biſk.
sp.p: Do but ſmell how I'm perfum'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Con.
sp.p: Ah! dear Son-in Law, don't come near me, your Perfumes ſtrike me dead, I'm all over Vapours.

sp.speaker: Biſk.
sp.p: Heigh day! good lack! why then my Eſſence is become a Nuiſance, I am ſorry I put myſelf to the Charge of offending you, and wiſh with all my Heart I had come as I us'd to do.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your natural Smell will ſoon get the better of thoſe ſtinking Sweets.

sp.speaker: Biſk.
sp.p: I vow I hope they will; I proteſt I thought Perfumes had been a Mark of Gentility.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Con.
sp.p: Well, the General has agreed to all our Propoſals, your Miſtreſs has conſented, and therefore you may in a few Hours prepare to be happy. I muſt about my Family Affairs.

sp.speaker: Biſk.
sp.p: I don't care how-ſoon the Ceremony is over, —for I met that terrible-looking Fellow, my Rival, juſt now, and he caſt ſuch an inveterate Eye at me, that my poor Heart has flutter'd up and down, like a wild Jack-Daw in a Wicker Cage, ever ſince.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh! there's no fear of him, I'll take care he ſhall not moleſt you, 'tis your Miſtreſs's Pleaſure you ſhould marry in the Dark, the Company is to be ſurpriz'd with your good Fortune, for you are to ſteal out one by one—I'll tell you when 'tis your Cue.

sp.speaker: Biſk.
sp.p: Adad very pretty, that will be wiping the Major's Noſe with one of my own Handkerchiefs. Thou art a delicate Creature, Mrs. Belinda, and for your good Offices, I proteſt when my Wife dies, you ſhall be my ſecond, if you pleaſe, (Aſide.) tho' I'd as lieve be married to the Devil.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well, when that Day comes, I ſhall claim your Promiſes, (Aſide.) tho' Death to me would be much pleaſanter to me than ſuch a Coxcomb— (to him.) Come, Sir, we'll go to your Miſtreſs, keep cloſe to her, leſt ſhe changes her Mind.

sp.speaker: Biſk.
sp.p: Oh! when ſhe ſees me thus compleatly dreſt, 'twill be impoſſible for her to deny me any thing; methinks I do look very bewitchingly, Belinda.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I have much a-do, to keep from admiring you.

sp.speaker: Biſk.
sp.p: Say'ſt thou ſo, poor Girl; why then I won't look lovely on you, but ſquint when I turn towards you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Come, keep your fine Words, and look for your Victoria.

sp.speaker: Biſk.
sp.p: I proteſt and ſo I will.

div.stage: Enter the Provoſt, ſeveral Criminals, Willmot in Chains, with a Guard, and Soldiers Wives.
div.p: Before they come in, they cry make Way there.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.p: Stand by, have a nice Eye upon that dogget Fellow, he has a very hanging Look.

sp.speaker: 1. Trull.
sp.p: Ah! my dear Huſband, I'm the unfortunateſt Woman in the World, to be married to eleven, and to have 'em all come to untimely Ends, 'tis a great Grief.

sp.speaker: 2. Trull.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis no Misfortune to you, it's what you have been us'd to, and uſe is a ſecond Nature; but I that have had thirteen Huſbands, and the laſt only to come to an ill end, 'tis a terrible, diſmal, horrid Story, ſo it is.

sp.speaker: 1. Crim.
sp.p: Prithee hold thy Tongue, I'd rather die than be ſent ſick to the Hoſpital; as for you, Moll, an I'm condem'd, I bequeath you to my Comrade.

sp.speaker: 2. Trull.
sp.p: Ah, good now, don't, dear Salt Petre, any Body but he my good Huſband.

sp.speaker: 1. Crim.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, Fool, 'tis my laſt Will and Teſtament, and I will have it obey'd, or I won't die quietly.

sp.speaker: 2. Trull.
sp.p: Cries.

sp.speaker: 2. Crim
sp.p: Well, Alice, my laſt dying Speech is e'en marry whom you will, all my Comfort is, when I'm once hang'd, I can't be married to you again.

sp.speaker: 1. Trull.
sp.p: Ah, ah, I knew you were nigh your end, by your talking ſo light headedly about the Wiſe of your Boſom.

sp.speaker: 1. Crim.
sp.p: Well, hanging to me is a ſtrange thing, I'm like a Fiſh out of Water—and don't know whether I ſhould repent of my Sins before I'm condemn'd, or after.

sp.speaker: 2. Crim.
sp.p: Ah, the ſooner you begin the better, for you have a woundy many to anſwer for; now thank my Stars, my Conſcience is not much troubled, I have only the common Army Sins, of whoring, drinking, thieving, murder, lie at my Door.

sp.speaker: Willm.
sp.p: Oh! horrid—ſuch wicked Wretches I never met with; the Miſery of ſuffering with 'em, is more than the Pains of Death can be—well, Fellow, what do we ſtand here for; why don't you lead on?

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.p: I loiter the Time away, that you may prepare yourſelf for dying, for you will be hang'd, Friend, very ſuddenly.

sp.speaker: Willm.
sp.p: Make haſte, and lead me to it; I wiſh for't, that I may be rid of thee, Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.p: Lookee, an you don't give good Words, you ſhan't be hang'd this Week, nay, may be never.

sp.speaker: 1. Crim.
sp.p: The Devil's in the Fellow I think, for provoking of him; would I was over Head and Ears in Death, and then I ſhould be out of my Pain.

sp.speaker: 2. Trull.
sp.p: I'm ſure I ſhall have no Comfort of my Life till 'tis over with you, either one way or other.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.p: Come—march on— (they go out in the Order they came in, and the Women cry)

div.stage: A Table and Chairs for the Court-Martial.
Enter Judge Advocate, and his Clerk.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: Come, take out the Copy of all the Courts-Martial, and lay the Articles of War, and the Book to ſwear Witneſſes with, in their proper order; we have but little Buſineſs To-day, no intricate perplexing Matters, nothing but down right Sentence of Death; it will be ſoon over.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Ah, there's a great deal of Pleaſure in our Trade, where a Man's Life depends upon one ſingle Article; a Sentence of Death is given in a Moment, but when they come to fending and proving, it occaſions a great deal of Writing.

div.stage: Enter Colonel Mackentoſh, Major O'Rourki, Major Buck, Cadwallader, Wildiſh, Hearty, Captain LaCunette, Surly, Rag, Standard, and three other Officers, to make up the Court-Martial.

sp.speaker: Col. Mac.
sp.p: Come, bonny Lads—tak your Seſſions according to'll your Qualities; our Officers are ſo ſackly, that we were forc't to ſummons aw you Subalterns; come, ſeat your ſals. Wall, Mr. Judge, lat us begin as ſoon as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, you are by Virtue of a Warrant,
ſign'd by the General, to enquire into all Complaints and Miſdemeanours that ſhall come before you; and upon Witneſs, or Confeſſion of the Party, you are to proceed to give judgment, according to the Articles of War. You have already been ſworn, Gentlemen, and may proceed

sp.speaker: Col. Mac.
sp.p: Have you a Liſt of the Priſoners, and their Crimes.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: It lies before your Honour.

sp.speaker: Cadw.
sp.p: Here, give it me, I will look it over.

sp.speaker: Col. Mac.
sp.p: (Snatches it from him.) waunds, that's when I have done with it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cadw.
sp.p: Coot now, what a Paſſion hur is in; if we were not upon Puſſineſs, hur cout be in as great a Paſſion as herſelf, Cot knows.

sp.speaker: Col. Mac.
sp.p: Well, my Ladds, an you thank fat we'll gang upon the Affairs.

sp.speaker: Aito.
sp.p: As ſoon as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: Call in John Tinder-Box, and the Witneſſes againſt him.

div.stage: Enter one Criminal, and two Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: (To the Witneſſes.) Come here, you. (He makes as if he ſwears 'em.)

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: Friend—what have you to ſay againſt the Priſoner?—ſtand forward.

sp.speaker: 1. Wit.
sp.p: Exce'entiſſimos Eſta Ladrono, Diabolo Soldada vincoe, me a cauſaitomar um porca & todos: neos couſes—per mangero—ſe ſenhor procerto.

sp.speaker: Maj. O'Rourk.
sp.p: By my Shoule, dear Joy, I do not think he is a good Vitneſs; for, as de Fellow muſt be try'd by the Laws of his own Country, ſo it ought to be upon de Allegatory of de Vitneſſes of his own Country too.

sp.speaker: Maj. Buck.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Country-man.

sp.speaker: Cadw.
sp.p: Look here now, this is a nice Point, and a very knotty Part of the Law.

sp.speaker: Col. Mac.
sp.p: Geud Sir, and you underſtand Portugueze as wile as oy, you'd find the Priſoner that is before you has been a Rogue, that has ſtole aw the Fellow's Vittals; I think we ſhould agree to hang him; what Deſance have you to mak for your ſal, Sir?

sp.speaker: Crim.
sp.p: Why, and pleaſe your Judge-ſhip, none at all, but that he's a Papiſh.

sp.speaker: Cadw.
sp.p: Well, that is a pretty Court Reaſon too.

sp.speaker: Maj. Buck.
sp.p: And your Hatred to his Religion made you ſteal his Proviſions.

sp.speaker: Crimi.
sp.p: I plunder'd him out of pure Zeal, noble Major; beſides, I muſt have ſtarv'd if I had not don't; ſo I plead the General Statute, which is, Neceſſity has no Law.

sp.speaker: Capt. Wild.
sp.p: Why, are you not paid your Subſiſt?

sp.speaker: Crim.
sp.p: Why, not enough to ſubſiſt on: One Year indeed I have a new Coat; next Year I make a Waiſtcoat on't; the third Year a Pair of Breeches; and after that, it makes a Cap; the Commiſſary of the Stores makes my Captain pay Four and Six-pence for an Iriſh Pair of Shoes, worth Half a Crown; and he ſtops but Five Shillings oat of my Subſiſt for 'em.

sp.speaker: Capt. Hearty.
sp.p: The Fellow looks as if he'd tell us our own.

sp.speaker: Crim.
sp.p: I have heard of Contingencies, and People's doing Juſtice; but I never met with any Thing but Stoppages and Hardſhips.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: Friend, the Court has been ſo favourable, as to give you the Liberty of juſtifying yourſelf, inſtead of which you are accuſing other Folks.

sp.speaker: Crim.
sp.p: No, Sir; I'm only ſhewing you, that their ſtealing from me, is the main Cauſe of my ſtealing from others.

sp.speaker: Capt. La Cu.
sp.p: He is a damn'd Rogue; he ought to be hang't for ſpeaking againſt all de Perquiſites of de Army.

sp.speaker: Cadw.
sp.p: Cot knows you are a Man of pritty Conſcience, to hang a Gentleman Soultier for ſpeaking Truth.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: (To the other Witneſs.) Are you a Witneſs, Friend?

sp.speaker: 2. Witn.
sp.p: I'm the Interpreter to this Portugueze, and will ſwear any Thing he ſays.

sp.speaker: Col. Mac.
sp.p: You may all withdraw, Sir; charge the Provoſt with his Priſoner there.

sp.speaker: Crim
sp.p: (to the Clerk.) Sir, here's half a Cruſade for you, only to tell me how you think it will go with me.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Why, Friend, you know I'm Sworn to Secreſy, but provided you'll never declare it to any Body, I will tell you.

sp.speaker: Crim.
sp.p: Not I, upon my Soul, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Then you'll certainly be hang'd, as I'm now alive.

sp.speaker: Crim.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you, it ſhall go no further for me.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: Call in Straitup, and the Witneſſes againſt him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: That's your ſine Gentleman I think, Major Buck.

sp.speaker: Maj. Buck.
sp.p: Yes truly a very ſine Fellow he would have Murdered his Officer.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: Stand there, Sir, what have you to ſay againſt the Priſoner?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: As I was upon my Duty, exerciſing ſome Soldiers, this Fellow behaved himſelf very awkwardly, and with an air of ſtubbornneſs, for which I very gently corrected him; he immediately preſented his Piece at me, and if it had not been for the Serjeant here, had ſhot me through the Head.

sp.speaker: File-off.
sp.p: Yes had I not prevented him, he had lodg'd a brace of Bullets in my Officer's Skull.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Wounds, Sir, this was an inſolency that an you had ran him through the Body, Sir, or cut him to pieces, ye had been juſtified, but we'll take care to ſee him hang'd, as an Example to aw bloody Rogues.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: Cot knows I am for roaſting him alive, hat you the Deſle pefore your Eyes, you Villain you

sp.speaker: O'Rourk.
sp.p: By my ſhoul he ſholt be twenty Years hanging upon a Gibbet, and then he will die a lingering Death.

sp.speaker: La Cu.
sp.p: Jerney blew, ſerve him like de Proteſtant in France.

sp.speaker: Willm.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, I'm ſenſible this Court has great Power, and therefore are Judges of Life and Death; I have long been weary of my Life, and wiſhed to have loſt it nobly in the Field; I was never us'd to Blows, and therefore the inſolence of this young Fellow provok'd the Paſſion, which led me into that raſh Action; and ſince your Sentence is paſs'd on me, I'll die contented,—but know I'm a Gentleman of a plentiful Eſtate, and good Family, in Cornwall; I was impoſed
on by an ungrateful Woman, whom I long had lov'd, her uſage forc'd me from my native Country, and was the cauſe of this my ſhameful Sentence! O cruel barbarous Charlotte!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! what do I here:

div.stage: ſhe ſwoons in the Serjeant's Arms.

sp.speaker: Major Buck.
sp.p: (Riſes.) What ails the young Fellow?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (Recovers.) Oh! Willmot, Willmot, wretched, moſt wretched Charlotte!

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Ha, did ſhe ſay Charlotte, Fool that I was, not to find her out; 'tis ſhe, 'tis ſhe, the perjur'd, charming, falſe deluding, Charlotte.

sp.speaker: Major Buck.
sp.p: 'Tis indeed a Woman, and a very ſoft bewitching one.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Waunds an Women begin to turn Officers, 'tis Time for Men to gang Hame about their affairs.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: The Clock has ſtruck One, ſo we muſt adjourn the Court till to-morrow at Ten.

sp.speaker: Maj. O'Rourk.
sp.p: By my Shoul, 'tis high Time to adjourn a Court, ven ſo intricate an Affair as this comes upon us.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: Cot knows, 'tis a point in Law, put if I was alone py my ſhelf, I could decite it to poth theirs Satisfactions.

sp.speaker: La Cu.
sp.p: 'Tis de very knotty point, a begar ve don't know veder he's to be married or hang'd.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Her ſits are very ſtrong, for Heaven's ſake, call the Ladies and acquaint the General with this accident, to him I'm known.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: That ſhall be my Arrant.

sp.speaker: Major Buck.
sp.p: if you have an Opportunity, acquaint Victoria with our deſign.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You may aſſure yourſelf I will.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (Recovers.) Oh! where's my Willmot?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Here, perfidious Charmer!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Have I run all the Hazards in the World to find thee out, repented of my ill uſage to thee, and thus far followed you to take away your Life, 'tis a grief I never can ſurvive.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: —Oh! Heavens what ails my dear Lady.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Oh! Clara, ſee there my Wilmot, no ſooner
found than loſt, and 'tis by my proſecution he muſt ſuffer Death.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Say not ſo, my dear Lady.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Waunds, Madam, an that be your Grief; we ſhall never hang a Man for a Woman, an you had been a real Officer, geud faith aw his Eſtate ſhou'd not have bought his Life.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: And is he not to ſuffer Death?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: An you dono kall him with kindneſs, he may live till he's weary of you.

sp.speaker: Maj. O'Rourk.
sp.p: By my Shoul, that is all our opinions.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: Nay, and it is mine too.

div.p: Enter Brigadier General Conqueſt, Mrs. Conqueſt, Belinda, and afterwards Wildiſh, and Victoria.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: (to Victoria.) nothing can redeem you but that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Con.
sp.p: Willmot, my dear Friend, it is with wonder and ſurpriſe, I've heard your Story.

sp.speaker: Wilm.
sp.p: See there, Sir, is your Niece Charlotte.

sp.speaker: Women.
sp.p: Charlotte!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Con.
sp.p: I'm all amazement, come to my Arms, my deareſt Child.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Couſin, this is romantick truly.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: Have you ſerv'd me ſo, Mad-cap; you are under my Command now, and I'll take care to give you a Poſt for Life; there, Willmot, lift her under you, and if ſhe offers to deſert, the Court Martial ſhe brought you too, is ſtill in being.

Come, Gentlemen, this is a joyful Day, you have been Judging on Life and Death; you now ſhall at the ſame Table, try the Cauſe over a Bottle: Some Wine here, pray uſe no Ceremony, you all are welcome.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Obſerve, Madam, how he eyes her (to Mrs. Conqueſt.) if you haſten not the Match, he certainly will find means to break it off, and then ſhe's miſerable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Con.
sp.p: The Chaplain is in the Parlour waiting for 'em, it ſhall be done immediately.

sp.speaker: Bis.
sp.p: A Woman my Friend, Mr. Hickumbuz, a Woman at laſt, and my Couſin that is to be; adad, if, I had known that as we Travel'd, I ſhould have made uſe of the Opportunity of lying in the ſame Room with her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Con.
sp.p:
(to her Husband.) My dear, I have particular Reaſons, for haſtening the Marriage, the Chaplain
waits for you in the Alcove, and the Room is darken'd.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: It ſhall be done forthwith— (to them.) come, Gentlemen, pray, drink about, Colonel Mackintoſh, my Service to you, this Couple's health. (pointing to Wilmot and Charlotte.)—I muſt beg your Pardons, for a Moment, I'll wait on you again, before the Bottle goes round, and we will be very merry (to Biſket unobſerv'd.) do you follow me to the Alcove, the Chaplain waits for you.

sp.speaker: Biſk.
sp.p: He ſhan't wait long for me, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: So my Father's gone, they need not have bid me counterfeit a Swoon; Heaven knows, I ſoon ſhall do it naturally.

sp.speaker: Major Buck.
sp.p: The General's gone, with a cue for me.

div.stage: Victoria ſwoons away in her Mother's Arms.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Con.
sp.p: Ha, what ails the Child!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Her ſwooning away was a lucky accident, and Major Buck, now muſt certainly be mine.

sp.speaker: Biſk.
sp.p: So, ſo, ſhe comes to herſelf, (ſpeaks to her.) I'll go to Father, you'll follow, deary.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Immediately.

sp.speaker: Biſk.
sp.p: Ah! Bisket, thou art a happy Dog.

sp.speaker: Mrs Con.
sp.p: So how is it, my dear?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Her Pulſe are very quick.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Oh! I muſt have a little Air, or I ſhall faint again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Con.
sp.p: Your Father waits for you.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: The open Air, Madam, or I ſhall die.

div.stage: Mrs. Conqueſt and Charlotte lead her out.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: The Women are all bewitch'd with ſwooning away, come, Mr. Willmot, will you drink a Bottle, at the ſame Table you had like to be condemned at?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: There is a ſtrange turn in my affairs, truly.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: Cot knows, the Tuty of a Husbant, is as grevious, as that of a Granadier, there is a goot deal of ſlavery in poth Services.

sp.speaker: O'Rourk.
sp.p: By my Shoul, Mr. Willmot, I can by my own knowledge, foretel, that your Life hither too, has been a very odd ſort of a one.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Begar, de Shentilman come into the Army, to
avoid his Maſtreſs—'tis very like a my caſe, for I come here to avoid my Wife begar, and ſhe is de Officer when ever ſhe pleaſſes.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come, Hearty, here's ſucceſs to Maj. Buck.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: We ſhall either be very merry, or blown up, my Heart aches for him.

sp.speaker: O'Rourk.
sp.p: By my Shoul, he is my Townſman, and my Heart does ache for him always, vedere he is in Danger or not.

sp.speaker: La Cu.
sp.p: He is de very pretty Gentleman, he has de very good underſtanding, and he ſeemed very much pleaſed vid my Battery, he has a pretty ſmattering in the Mattematicks, allons Bouvont Chante he Sings.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: Cot pleſs hur, what a ſilly Language is here, come hur will Sing hur a Welſh Song, ſet to the Muſick of Wales. be Sings.

sp.speaker: O'Rourk.
sp.p: By my Shoul, dear Joy, where is de Engliſh of that now.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: Cot knows, 'tis an Original, and you have no Engliſh that can expreſs it.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Well, of aw your Songs, there's neen like the Bag Pipe Tweedales of Sawny and Jockey.

sp.speaker: Enter Mrs.
sp.p: Conqueſt, Victoria, and Charlotte.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Con.
sp.p: So, my Dear, I'm glad to ſee you recover'd, your Father, and Mr. Bisket wait impatiently for you in the Alcove, the Rooms are darken'd on purpoſe as you deſir'd.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: What will be the end of this Day's Work, and what has Major Buck done, to ſave me from this Coxcomb ha—

div.stage: Enter Major Buck, be ſmiles on her, and ſleals to bis Place at the Table.
div.p: He ſeems pleas'd, and comes from the Parlour; then ſure I may venture to advance, Madam, (to her Mother.) I hope you'll attend me to my Father.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Con.
sp.p: Moſt willingly, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: And my Dear Couſin too. they go towards the Stage Door. Brig. Gen. Conqueſt ſpeaks without.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: You would have the Frolick of being married in the Dark, but I'll lead you to the light, and we will be very merry.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Con.
sp.p: What ſays my Huſband?

div.stage: He enters with Biſket in one Hand, and Belinda in the other.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: Hell and Furies, what a miſtake is this?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Torment and Confuſion, am I outwitted, Condemn'd to this Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Bis.
sp.p: Ah, Gemini, I have brought my Hogs to a Fair Market, Couzen'd by ſuch a—ſo ſo Creature, when my Head run of nothing but the beautiful Victoria, I'll go and hang myſelf, and ſo be dvorc'd.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: See how the Monſter Triumphs in his Looks, I'll go where I may never ſee him more.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: Who can unfold this trickiſh Riddle?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Con.
sp.p: I fear Victoria is deeply concern'd in this Plot, I know ſhe hated Bisket mortally.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: Did ſhe ſo, why then I'm glad ſhe miſſed him.

sp.speaker: Major Buck.
sp.p: Ha! there's ſome Hope for me, ſo I muſt Beg your Pardon, when I tell you I was the cauſe of this Miſtake, I doated on your Daughter, but by the ill-natured Contrivances of Belinda, found it was impoſſible to make my Addreſſes known; hearing your Daughter deſir'd to be married in the Dark, I directed a Letter for her, but took care it ſhould fall into Belinda's Hands, wherein I offer'd to perſonate the Santiſta, ſhe believing I would drop into the Snare I lay'd for her, which was the only means I e'er could Hope to ſave Victoria from the Man ſhe hates.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: I did indeed deſign Bisket for my Daughter's Huſband, but ſince you have order'd it otherwiſe, Sir, I ſhall be proud of your Alliance I knew your Father well, and your behaviour in the Army has not leſſen'd my Eſteem of your Family, here, Victoria, ſince he has taken this Pains about you, I think he deſerves you.

sp.speaker: Major Buck.
sp.p: I receive her with all the Joy Imaginable.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Very much with my Inclinations I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Con.
sp.p: Nay, ſince it is ſo, I wiſh you happy.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: May ye be as happy, as 'tis poſſible for married Folks to be.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: Sir, I was ſent Expreſs from the Generals at Eſtermas with this Packet.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: (Reads.) Ha!—then the ſhow is over, and there's no more Work for us. Gentlemen here's an Order to proclaim a Geſſation of Arms for four Months, between Britain, France, and Spain.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Wounds, Sir, then I'll gang to Edinburgh, and live cheap upon half pay.

sp.speaker: O'Rourk.
sp.p: By my Shoule, I will go into the County of Tipperary, where I can live cheaper than you, for fait now I can live for nothing.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: I will go to my Seat in Wales, and keep my hant in with Shooting of Hares and Rabbits, and WildFowls, I will fatten myſelf up with Welſh Ale, and pray for another War.

sp.speaker: La Cu.
sp.p: Vat muſt the poor French Gentilman do?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: You muſt take Lodgings in Scho, Sir, make Perriwigs, and ſhave for two Pence.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Thank our Stars, Wildiſh, ours is an old Regiment, and we ſhall be turn'd adriſt at laſt.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: We poor Subs have but a diſmal proſpect.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Well, Brother Lieutenant, 'ts better than fighting of Duels tho'.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.p: Truly, fair Laty, it was a goot Jeſt, that I mait up the matter, or he woot have pin too ſtrong for you.

sp.speaker: 1 Enſign.
sp.p: Come, Brother, let's ſteal off, for I am very uneaſy with all this money in my Pocket.

sp.speaker: Brig. Gen. Con.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, after ſo long a War, 'tis high Time that we ſhould all retire, that our Nation may Recruit the Blood and Treaſure they have loſt.

lg.l: The Turns and Toſſes that we meet abroad,
In our Retirement Pleaſure will afford:
Britons have gain'd in War a glovious Name,
And Soldiers will be eccbo'd out by Fame.
But ſince the Nation's Welfare to encreaſe,
All boſtile Jars and warlike Acts muſt ceaſe,
The Scns of Mars ſhall be rever'd in Peace.

div.p: ERRATUM. For Captain Luconnel, read every where Captain La Cunette.
